data.title: How a Fantasy Book Can Smooth Your Hackles About a Real Place
data.meta_description: Florida made my mind turn against itself. Aggravation from being there too long made me trip and fall on simple walks. Injuries piled up. Something in the Floridian air gave my skin strange…
data.text:
“All things make sense; you just have to fathom how they make sense.” — Piers Anthony

A Superpower of Books Changes My World

Stories can turn around the attitude of even the staunchest of haters. I hated Florida.

Florida made my mind turn against itself. Aggravation from being there too long made me trip and fall on simple walks. Injuries piled up.

Something in the Floridian air gave my skin strange, never-ending issues. Its lack of winter stole Christmas. Madmen drivers fill the streets, and you can only navigate by U-turns. Etcetera, etcetera.

“You should try Piers Anthony,” a friend told me. Why? Because in my troubles, I had turned back to fantasy reading.

Piers Anthony is a prolific fantasy author. Yet I had never tried him! After browsing his titles, I picked up “A Spell for Chameleon.” It’s the first book in Anthony’s widely-beloved, 35-book-long Xanth series. (Fans sometimes affectionately call him “Pier Xanthony”).
